title: Part A: Thesis
stimulusHtml:
A thesis statement expresses a defensible interpretation of a text.

The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.
descriptions: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
Responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the passage.

title: Part B: Evidence and Commentary
stimulusHtml:
Commentary establishes and explains relationships among textual evidence, the line of reasoning, and the thesis.

To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the passage.

Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the last point in this row.

In Unit 6, students examine how a character’s own choices, actions, and speech reveal complexities in that character and thus contribute to complexity in a text. This preparation should be useful to students as they approach this passage and task.

At this point in the course, students should continue to focus on developing the skills necessary to consistently provide specific evidence and explain how that evidence supports a line of reasoning. Active planning and reflection throughout the writing process can help students identify opportunities in their own work to further develop their thinking or enhance their arguments. Starting in unit 7, students may be able to earn a point in Part C for demonstrating sophistication of thought and/or developing a complex literary argument.
